source.description:
Fill the plastic slide box with
.
Rest the coverslipped slides on the interior raised edges of slide box such that they are inverted (ie. coverslip down and barcode up).
If your next round is a staining round, prepare your dilutions while you are waiting for the coverslips to come off.

Be patient - within
-
, coverslips should naturally come off.

source.title: Calculating Ab Amount for Ab Dilution Cocktails

source.description: The following section should be used when making cocktails of antibodies for any type of experiment including primary/secondary (P/S), antigen effects (AE), direct conjugates (DC), and revalidation (RV). This includes running 2 different P/S antibodies or conjugates with 2 different dyes on the same slide at the same time. For P/S antibodies, the species (Rabbit IgG, Mouse IgG1, etc) must be different to run on the same slide at the same time.

source.title: Calculating Ab Amount for Ab Dilution Cocktails

source.description: Determine the total volume that will be needed for the experiment.

source.title: Calculating Ab Amount for Ab Dilution Cocktails

source.description: Determine the stock concentration for the antibodies. This should be written on the barcode or label on the antibody. If there is no concentration written on the vial or the datasheet contact either the vendor and/or chemist who prepared it and ask. Provide the catalog number and lot#, if applicable.

source.title: Calculating Ab Amount for Ab Dilution Cocktails

source.description:
Once a concentration is obtained for an antibody, determine the final concentration the antibodies or conjugates should be run at.
If the antibody/DC is new and commercially available and no final concentration is noted on the vendor datasheet, call the vendor to ask. If no final concentration can be recommended, run the new marker at

source.title: Calculating Ab Amount for Ab Dilution Cocktails

source.description: For manual workflow, this is typically (200μL*#of slides)

source.title: Calculating Ab Amount for Ab Dilution Cocktails

source.description:
Use the following formula to calculate the required amount for each antibody (Ab):
  • stock concentration * X = final concentration Ab1 * total volume needed for experiment
  • stock concentration * X = final concentration Ab2 * total volume needed for experiment
  • Solve for X in each case to determine how many μL of each antibody/DC will be required.
  • Subtract the sum of the Ab volumes together from the total volume to get the volume of Ab diluent (3% BSA in PBS) that needs to be added.

source.body: For example: if and was used, the sum of Ab volumes= . Subtract this volume from the total volume needed for the experiment to obtain the volume of Ab diluent to add to the Abs.

source.title: Calculating Ab Amount for Ab Dilution Cocktails

source.description:
If you are using secondary antibodies, determine the volume you will need for the secondary in the same manner described above for calculating for the primary antibody/DC. Secondary antibodies are stained at a final concentration of
. Determine which secondaries you need based on the isotypes of the P/S antibodies used.

source.title: Calculating Ab Amount for Ab Dilution Cocktails

source.description: Determine if there is a dye preference for each marker (ie. Some markers look better in Cy3 or Cy5). If there is no preference, make the marker that has lower expression in Cy3 if possible.

source.body: Check to make sure the dyes are different when making cocktails with DCs. For P/S antibodies, different species as well as different dyes must be used for each antibody. For example, a mouse IgG1 antibody and a rabbit IgG antibody could be pooled; an example of pooled secondary antibodies to use would Cy3-Donkey-anti-mouse and Cy5-Donkey-anti-rabbit.

source.description: If you are trying to characterize a new primary-secondary antibody, refer to Study Design & Process Flow (Step 27)
If you are trying to validate a new directly conjugated antibody, proceed to New Direct Conjugate Validation Study Design (Step 72).
If you are trying to re-validate a directly conjugated antibody (new lot/batch), proceed to Revalidating Directly Conjugated Antibodies (Step 86).
If you are trying to validate Zenon labelling, proceed to Zenon Labeling (step 98).
If you are studying antigen effects for a given antibody, proceed to Overview of Experimental Design for Testing Antigen Effects to Dye Inactivation (step 123).
Slides are coverslipped to protect the tissue from drying out.

Mounting media should be removed from the
fridge and brought to
.
Slides should be quickly dipped in ddH2O.
Take a rainin pipet tip (200μL-green box) and with a scissors clip the end to make a wide bore.

Take up
and add to one end of the slide. For leaching markers, use alternate mounting media (50% glycerol, 4% propyl gallate).

source.title: mounting media (4% propyl gallate, 1% DABCO, 90% glycerol)

source.description: Place the end of the coverslip at a 45 degree angle and slowly lower; allowing the mounting media to flow under the coverslip across the slide.
Make sure there is not mounting media oozing out of the sides of the coverslip; remove any excess by gently blotting on a Kimwipe.

Proceed to Imaging as per the Cell DIVE™ Imaging manual or store the slides at
in light protected environment. (Recommendation: image within 24 hours of staining.)

Below is a schematic that provides an overview of the experiment design for antibody characterization for primary-secondary staining. Depending on the slide type (ie, cell pellet vs TMA) and scenario (ie, controls on the slide), a certain experimental design is required. The user should map their scenario to the corresponding study design they must execute.

8TMA with positive and negative control tissue; primary antibody does not have peptide blockStain with primary/secondary antibodiesStain with isotype control followed by secondary stain

If your study requires Phosphatase Pretreatment, proceed to Controls—Phosphatase Pretreatment of Tissue (step 51).
If your study requires Immunizing Peptide Block, proceed to Controls—Blocking with Immunizing Peptide (step 60).
If your study requires Isotype Controls, proceed to Controls—Isotype Controls (step 66).

Retrieve primary antibody from the
walk-in refrigerator or
freezer. Be sure to keep
at all times.

Spin the stock antibody down at
. If stock antibodies are in large or odd shaped vials, transfer them to eppendorf tubes and label appropriately with a LIMS sticker (if possible, remove the LIMS label from the original vial and stick it on the eppendorf tube).

Make up primary antibody dilutions in the antibody diluent solution (
/
) using the manufacturer suggested concentration of antibody, with the exceptions noted.

source.body:
• If there is no concentration suggested, then use 5 µg/ mL.
  • If the vendor suggests < 1 µg/ mL, then increase it to 1µg/ mL (when performing incubation).
  • If no concentration or recommended dilution is available, use a 1:100 dilution.

The peptide blocking experiment should be done alongside a primary/secondary antibody staining experiment.

Retrieve peptide from
walk-in refrigerator or
freezer and keep
.

Use the manufacturer’s suggested concentration of peptide (if not indicated on datasheet call vendor); if there is not a concentration recommended then use 100-fold molar excess of peptide to antibody.

source.body: If you are unsure in how to calculate this please consult your study coordinator.

source.description:
Use the concentration of primary antibody suggested as per
in the Primary - Secondary Antibody Section.

Dilute peptide and primary antibody in the antibody diluent buffer (
/

at

Add peptide & primary antibody solution to slide and follow remaining steps in Primary - Secondary Antibody starting at
.
The isotype control experiment should be done alongside a primary/secondary antibody staining experiment. The isotype control employed should match the IgG type of the primary antibody.

source.body: The same isotype control can be used for antibodies that have the same IgG type if the final concentration used for the antibodies is ≤ 5µg/mL. Any antibody that has a final concentration of > 5µg/mL needs its own isotype control even though it may have the same IgG type as another antibody.

source.description: Double-check the correct isotype control is being used.
If the isotype is a Mouse IgG1 or Rabbit IgG1, use the Cell Signaling Isotype controls. If it is Mouse IgG2a,2b or Rat, etc use the R&D isotype controls.

Retrieve isotype control from
or
storage location and keep
.

Use equivalent concentration of isotype control as what is used for the primary antibody. Dilute the isotype control in the antibody diluent buffer (
/
).

Proceed to Primary - Secondary Antibody starting at
.

source.description: For the Primary-Secondary Staining slide, use the purified form of the primary antibody if the antibody was purified prior to the conjugation (test at the same concentration used in the P/S experiment).

source.body: The slides used for this experiment must be tissue representative of what will be employed for the multiplexing experiment. The purpose is to determine the optimal concentration of direct conjugate to employ for multiplexing.

Zenon labeling provides a fast alternative way of conjugating antibodies. An unlabeled antibody is incubated with fluorophore-labeled Fab fragment and then mixed with a non-specific IgG to neutralize any extra unbound Fab fragments. The initial antibody does not require purification, prior to or after labeling.
An initial zenon experiment begins by targettng a 3:1 dye to protein ratio and staining at concentrations of
and
.
AB
1Zenon KitVendor and Cat. No.
2Zenon® Alexa Fluor® 555 Rabbit IgGInvitrogen Z25305
3Zenon® Alexa Fluor® 555 Mouse IgG1Invitrogen Z25005
4Zenon® Alexa Fluor® 555 Mouse IgG2bInvitrogen Z25205
5Zenon® Alexa Fluor® 647 Rabbit IgGInvitrogen Z25308
6Zenon® Alexa Fluor® 647 Mouse IgG1Invitrogen Z25008
7Zenon® Alexa Fluor® 647 Mouse IgG2bInvitrogen Z25208

AB

5Zenon® Alexa Fluor® 647 Rabbit IgGInvitrogen Z25308
6Zenon® Alexa Fluor® 647 Mouse IgG1Invitrogen Z25008
7Zenon® Alexa Fluor® 647 Mouse IgG2bInvitrogen Z25208

source.description: Zenon labeling validation is a 3 slide experiment: slide 1 - P/S, slides 2 and 3 - titration of zenon complexes. Prepare 3 bullet tubes for the initial zenon labeling validation.
The IgG concentration of Ab should be known. If unknown, contact vendor. If no concentration can be supplied, assume 200 µg/mL.

source.title: Overview of Experimental Design for Testing Antigen Effects to Dye Inactivation

source.description:
There should be a total of 4 slides prepared for testing the dye inactivation/bleaching effects. Slide 1 will not be treated with the dye inactivation solution, Slide 2 will be treated with 1 round of dye inactivation, Slide 3 will be treated with 5 rounds of dye inactivation, and Slide 4 will be treated with 10 rounds of dye inactivation.
ABCDE
1Treatment
2No Dye InactivationSlide 1
31 Round of Dye InactivationSlide 2
45 Rounds of Dye InactivationSlide 3
510 Rounds of Dye InactivationSlide 4

ABCDE
1Treatment
2No Dye InactivationSlide 1
31 Round of Dye InactivationSlide 2
45 Rounds of Dye InactivationSlide 3
510 Rounds of Dye InactivationSlide 4

source.title: Overview of Experimental Design for Testing Antigen Effects to Dye Inactivation

source.description: Make fresh dye inactivation solution.

source.body: Refer to the working solution for dye inactivation. The hydrogen peroxide is added to the solution immediately before adding to the staining dish. This reaction is time sensitive.

source.title: Overview of Experimental Design for Testing Antigen Effects to Dye Inactivation

source.description:
Within one minute of making the dye inactivation solution, pipet
onto slides 2, 3, and 4 in a humidified chamber containing water. (If there are many slides, use a staining dish containing
).

Incubate at
for
. Do not place parafilm over the slides.

source.description:
Remove slide 2 and transfer to
. Wash 3x for 5 minutes with gentle agitation on shaker and hold in PBS.

source.title: Overview of Experimental Design for Testing Antigen Effects to Dye Inactivation

source.description:
Perform a quick
wash (less than one minute) for slides 3 and 4 and continue bleaching, making a fresh dye inactivation solution for each round.

source.title: Overview of Experimental Design for Testing Antigen Effects to Dye Inactivation

source.description:
For slide 3, continue to 5 rounds of dye inactivation and for slide 4 continue to 10 rounds of dye inactivation.
Perform a quick
wash between each round.

source.title: Go/No Go Decision: Primary Secondary Antibody staining

source.description:
Compare antibody images to corresponding control slides.
    ABC
    1Type Of ComparisonType Of EvaluationNormalized To
    2Specificity• primary/secondary vs. Isotype controls or phosphatase pretreatment • three positives and one negative control tissue • if there is not a negative control use an internal negative controlprimary/secondary
    3Specificity• Primary/secondary of antibody 1 vs. Primary/secondary of antibody 2 vs. primary/secondary of antibody 3 vs. DABAuto-level each
    4Difference in intensity• Primary/secondary of antibody 1 vs. Primary/secondary of antibody 2 vs. primary/secondary of antibody 3To brightest specific primary

3Specificity• Primary/secondary of antibody 1 vs. Primary/secondary of antibody 2 vs. primary/secondary of antibody 3 vs. DABAuto-level each

source.description: Select the antibody with the best specificity (localization same as vendor/literature/collaborator suggested) and signal.

source.title: Go/No Go Decision: Primary Secondary Antibody staining

source.description: For troubleshooting on staining, refer to Figure 1: Troubleshooting Primary Antibody Characterization Flow Chart.

The direct conjugate staining should have comparable localization to the primary/secondary antibody and DAB images.
    ABC
    1Type Of ComparisonType Of EvaluationNormalized To
    2Specificityprimary/secondary vs. direct conjugatesAuto-level each
    3Intensityprimary/secondary vs. direct conjugatesNormalize to primary/secondary
    4Intensitydirect conjugates vs. direct conjugatesNormalize to brightest most specific direct conjugate

ABC
1Type Of ComparisonType Of EvaluationNormalized To
2Specificityprimary/secondary vs. direct conjugatesAuto-level each
3Intensityprimary/secondary vs. direct conjugatesNormalize to primary/secondary
4Intensitydirect conjugates vs. direct conjugatesNormalize to brightest most specific direct conjugate
Down select the D/P and concentration that yields the maximal signal to noise ratio.
For the troubleshooting workflow, refer to Figure 2: Direct Conjugate Troubleshooting Workflow.

source.title: Go/No Go Decision: Revalidating Direct Conjugates

source.description:
The new direct conjugate staining should have comparable localization to the old direct conjugate lot.
    ABC
    1To Be ComparedTo Be Evaluated Normalized To
    2SpecificityOLD direct conjugate vs. NEW direct conjugate vs. primary/secondary antibody vs. DABAuto-level each
    3IntensityOLD direct conjugate vs. NEW direct conjugateNormalize to old lot

ABC
1To Be ComparedTo Be Evaluated Normalized To
2SpecificityOLD direct conjugate vs. NEW direct conjugate vs. primary/secondary antibody vs. DABAuto-level each
3IntensityOLD direct conjugate vs. NEW direct conjugateNormalize to old lot

source.title: Go/No Go Decision: Revalidating Direct Conjugates

source.description: Maximize the signal to noise ratio.

Select the treated slide with the “no dye inactivation” slide (Slide 1).
    ABC
    1Type Of ComparisonType Of EvaluationNormalized To
    2Specificity“No Dye Inactivation” vs. historical images from primary down selection experiment vs. DAB imagesAuto-level each
    3Specificity“No Dye Inactivation” vs. dye inactivation roundAuto-level each
    4Difference in intensity“No Dye Inactivation” vs. dye inactivation round“No Dye Inactivation” slide

ABC
1Type Of ComparisonType Of EvaluationNormalized To
2Specificity“No Dye Inactivation” vs. historical images from primary down selection experiment vs. DAB imagesAuto-level each
3Specificity“No Dye Inactivation” vs. dye inactivation roundAuto-level each
4Difference in intensity“No Dye Inactivation” vs. dye inactivation round“No Dye Inactivation” slide

No antigen effects from dye inactivation is defined as:
  • No greater than 20% loss in stain intensity between “no dye inactivation” vs. other rounds.
  • Stain specificity is maintained.
  • Tissue integrity is maintained.
  • Non specific background staining is minimal.
Take a plastic slide box and place it in secondary containment.
Refer to Cell DIVE™ Imaging Manual.
There should be a maximal signal to noise ratio.

Wash slides for 3x
with
, using gentle agitation on shaker.

Wash slides for 3x
with
, using gentle agitation on shaker.

Note: If an antibody is not successful as a direct conjugate, options for including that antibody in a multiplex are as follows:
  • Try validation with another dye
  • Use with secondary detection. If performing Primary/Secondary staining, an IgG block to the isotype of the primary antibodies used should be performed at a 10-fold concentration. This should occur before staining a direct conjugate raised in the same species. For example: If isotypes of the primary antibodies were mouse IgG and Rabbit IgG, then after dye inactivating that round of staining, slides should be blocked in a cocktail rabbit and mouse serum for 30 minutes before proceeding to the next round of staining.
  • Look for a commercial conjugate
  • Try zenon labeling

source.title: Go/No Go Decision: Primary Secondary Antibody staining

source.description: Note: If performing Primary/Secondary staining in the first round of staining of a multiplex, an IgG block to the isotype of the primary antibodies used, should be performed at a 10-fold concentration. For example: If isotypes of the primary antibodies were mouse IgG and Rabbit IgG, then after bleaching the first round of staining, slides should be blocked in a cocktail rabbit and mouse serum for 30 minutes before proceeding to the second round of staining.

description: This protocol describes the process of validating antibodies (primary/secondary, direct conjugates, and zenon labelled) as per the Cell DIVE™ technology. It also describes the process for determining any antigen effects from the dye inactivation process.
